Hello,

I got an error 500 when trying OWA access right after entering my credentials. From Microsoft website I found :

This error occurs when the name in the SSL client request from ISA Server does not match the common name on the Web site certificate. Check that the certificate names follow the guidelines:
For the certificate on the ISA Server computer, the name must match the name that the external clients specify to reach the site.
For the certificate on the published Web server, the name must match the name that appears on the To tab of the rule.
In the case of the certificate on the Web server in a server publishing scenario, the certificate should have the name that users will use to connect to the server.

So I need 2 different certificates ? One for Clients->TMG and one for TMG->Exchange ?

You would probably have installed Microsoft Office 2007 filter Packs before. I would suggest you install the Microsoft Office 2010 filter Packs as well.

*Edit*
Check that you have both Microsoft Office 2007 and 2010 filter Packs installed.
You only need one certificate. You need to ensure that you have the correct netbios and fqdn's in your certificate.

Just a note which will hopefully save someone an hour of frustration! If, when you import the CAS / Web server cert, you are not prompted for a password (even if the import is successful) and subsequently TMG still reports the cert as 'Invalid', check that you are importing a .pfx file, and not a .cer file! I made this mistake because when I exported my cert to .pfx I gave it the same name as another existing .cer file, and since the cert selection defaults to showing only .cer files, I was inadvertently selecting the .cer with the same base name as the .pfx file... Maybe naming them something different is better? :D

Hi Sam,

Yeah! the lack of password prompt/'invalid' certificate in TMG is because the .cer does not contain the private key. I've not experienced this myself but I can see how it may be slightly confusing. Thanks for calling it out.

Cheers,
Chris

I agree that it is no silver bullet, but I think it is worth giving them credit for taking a step in the right direction.

Thanks for the work you've done on this series. It is an excellent resource. I have a couple of questions that apply to my installation, which is a little different, but may be of interest to others. In order to provide redundancy, I am setting up TMG in an array configuration which will have 2 array members and a separate Configuration Storage Server. I plan on usinf Network Load Balancing to provide a virtual ip. Do I run through this process for each array member separately, as well as the CSS? Are the array members still NOT domain members? Is the CSS joined to the domain? Are there any other differences I should be aware of. Thanks again.

Hello Sean,

Thanks for your comments.

To be perfectly honest, I have not personally tried that configuration. I suspect it would be possible, however, I would not load balance SMTP (the Edge transport role) and use MX records with different preferences instead. Using NLB for the https workloads should be ok. Here is some guidance on TMG HA: http://technet.microsoft.co...

To answer you other questions:

<li>Yes, both members would not be joined to the domain.</li>
<li>The CSS will be domain joined</li>
<li>You would need to install each member separately and then configure the rules at array level</li>

Hope this helps. Email me if you would like to bounce ideas off someone.

Cheers.

Chris

What I found is that the HCW creates the organization relationship with the first domain in the list of hybrid domains specified sorted in alphabetical order (regardless of the order you specify them with Set-HybridConfiguration). The requirement for autodiscover to be configured for all domains seems only to be for cross org free-busy lookups for those domains, but what if you don't have a requirement for that? Well, if the first domain alphabetically happens to have autodiscover configured, the HCW will run successfully. However,if the first domain does NOT have a valid autodiscover DNS/certificate configuration, then the Get-FederationInformation for that domain will fail and HCW will bomb.
Thanks Ibrahim!

Thanks for the additional info Steve.

Cheers,

Chris

Also, option 2 won't work either, from ExDeploy checklist and my personal research I can say that Microsoft only support configuring autodicover with an A record (the option 1 in this article) or with a CNAME. Anything else won't work.

Thanks for the reply Aloisio. Yes, Option 1 is the only option that will work. The other options are purely for on-premise deployments.

Cheers,

Chris

The diagram that was posted by David is very interesting and I haven't considered it before either. It does differentiate Passive (web browser) and Rich clients (Lync), however, leaves out Active clients, such as Outlook.

I can see this working for passive authentication clients, such as web browsers. If an end user is redirected to their AD FS Service name appropriately, it doesn't matter as the integrated logon process will handle it. Even if they are using Firefox and seeing a form, or hitting the Web Application Proxy, end users can enter their UPN, Email address, or even domain\samaccountname.

For this to work, there are a couple of considerations
1. The UPN's must match, as you have already stated.
2. However, the UPN in your on premises AD must also be an internet routable FQDN - you would not be able to use an @domain.local UPN, for example (need to be able to verify it in Office 365). I have worked with a customer to deploy the original solution posted in Chris's article and they were heavily using (hundreds of) application that relied on the UPN suffix of @domain.int, or similar, and were very reluctant to change it. Chris' original article worked for them, as office 365 was populated with an SMTP address, also their internet routable UPN by using the DirSync customisation. However, if you are not using this part, you would still need to use an internet routable domain that they own.

For Active clients such as Outlook 2010/2013, I think there is an additional concern that you would need to think about.

Keep in mind that Outlook never actually directly communicates with AD FS. Autodiscover kicks in and an end user enters their email address, let's say john.smith@domain1.com. Exchange online actually presents the user with an authentication prompt. The end user enters their credentials, let's say john.smith@domain1.com. However, the UPN, as Office 365 determines it to be is johns@domain1.com.

Office 365 then looks up domain1.com to see if it is federated or managed. If it is federated, it will look up the AD FS service name associated to that domain - let's say sts.company.com. Office 365 then passes those credentials to that service name, usually a Web Application Proxy, and then passes to AD FS for processing.

This scenario, as described above should work (I think - I am pretty sure Office 365 doesn't actually check to make sure user john.smith@domain1.com exists before passing the auth requests to sts.company.com. If it does, Outlook wouldn't work without the DirSync alteration). But there is an additional consideration that I can see, in addition to the first two:

1. The UPN's must match, like with passive (browser) above,
2. The UPN must be internet routable, like with passive (browser) above
3. The UPN suffix and SMTP suffix (@domain1.com) need to also match*, so that Office 365 knows which AD FS service name to look up and where to send the credentials to.
a. *In the case they don't match, you could also look at the possibility of registering both the UPN suffix and SMTP suffix in the same AD FS service with the -SupportMultipleDomain switch. This may work but you might want to test it out.

Also I logged a ticket with Microsoft Online Services to see if they supported any of these scenarios, and the answer was "no". The reply I got back was

Issue Definition
Using Alternate Login IDs with ADFS on 2012 R2
 
Scope Agreement
We will consider this case closed when your question clarified.
  
Analysis
About the question of support boundary of cloud service, as you could see from the document you already found, http://technet.microsoft.co..., that during the steps of the configuration, the connectors of Active Directory Synchronization would need to be modified.
 
This would exceed Office 365 support team's support expertise and boundary. As you have found in http://technet.microsoft.co...

That's not to say that Premier Support won't support it - they probably would. But Microsoft Online Services are particular about what they support.

Hi Brendan,

Thanks for the very detailed reply. It certainly clarifies the support stance.

@David, have you tested all client access scenarios in your testing?

Also, the Active authentication mechanism is used by a bunch of other applications/protocols, such as POP3, IMAP, SMTP, PowerShell, and ActiveSync.

These would also need to be tested as well.

Hi Chris,

Your script could read the DomainName value from the RemoteDomain that is TargetDeliveryDomain = $True. The domain for the RemoteDomain that has this setting $True is the domain used for the TargetAddress attribute stamping against the email address policy. This way you do not need to ask the administrator for the value, or at least supply the value configured during the hybrid wizard.

"(Get-RemoteDomain | Where {$_.TargetDeliveryDomain -eq $True}).DomainName.Domain" returns the value of the mail routing domain

Hi Chris,

You might be interested in two options that make this easier. In the v5 preview of PowerShell (and in PowerShell 4.0 on fully-patched Windows 8.1 / 2012 R2 computers), there are new cmdlets called Protect-CmsMessage and Unprotect-CmsMessage. You give them a certificate and the data you want to encrypt / decrypt, and they take care of the rest (while producing standards-based CMS output to represent the encrypted data.)

Also, I wrote a module called ProtectedData (available on GitHub and PowerShellGet) which does much the same thing, but is compatible all the way back to PowerShell 2.0, and has a few other features that the CmsMessage cmdlets don't. (However, its output is not the CMS standard format, which means there's little to no chance for cross-platform utility.) Under the hood, it does almost exactly what you're doing here, but the calling code is much simplified:

$Cert = Get-ChildItem Cert:\LocalMachine\My | Where-Object {$_.Subject -like "CN=PowerShell Automation*"}

# To encrypt:
Protect-Data 'MyPassword' -Certificate $Cert -SkipCertificateVerification | Export-Clixml .\encrypted.xml

# To decrypt:
Unprotect-Data (Import-Clixml .\encrypted.xml) -Certificate $Cert -SkipCertificateVerification

Really well written article - thanks. You mentioned only one public folder migration can run at a time which makes sense. What doesn't make much sense (probably only to me - and not through any fault of your post) is whether you can run a public folder migration at the same time as a mailbox migration.

The MS article says you need to migrate mailboxes before you migrate public folders but doesn't say whether you actually need to go all the way and finalize them. Can you do the initial mailbox sync via the Office 365 mailbox migration tool in the EAC, do the public folder migration using this scripted method, then finalize both the mailbox and public folder migrations at the same time? Otherwise, Outlook gets moved over to Office 365 while public folders are still sat on the legacy on-premises Exchange Server inaccessible.

Hi Ken,

Thanks for your feedback.

In a typical migration scenario, you would move all your mailboxes to Exchange Online over time which means there will be a period of coexistence required which is what a Hybrid deployment of Exchange allows. During this time, users who have had their mailbox moved to Exchange Online can still access legacy public folders using proxy public folder mailboxes (see: Step 1 https://technet.microsoft.c... Once the mailbox move is complete and everyone has been moved to Exchange Online you would perform the Public Folder migration which really is a cut-over of all Public Folders at one time.

I guess you probably could try finalizing all mailboxes and cutting over the Public Folders at the same time, this probably would not be the best idea if you had a large number of users but for small environments it might work ok. I'll be honest, it isn't something that I've tried.

All the best,

Chris

Hi Mike,

Thanks for getting in touch!

You are correct, Exchange online does have some great options built into the product and I would definitely recommend using the hybrid migration approach if it makes sense for you. These tools are intended to take care of migration scenarios that are not covered by the default options or where there are constraints that prevent you from using the default options. Examples of these are:
<li>Exchange Online to Exchange Online migrations</li>
<li>Migrations from other non-Microsoft platforms</li>
<li>Small or legacy environments (like Exchange 2003) where it may not make sense to update to a new version first</li>

MigrationWiz does require access to EWS on your on-premises CAS server. I have not spent much time analyzing the privacy policies of any of these tools so I can't really comment on that. Obviously if you see something in there that you don't like, you could reach out to them for clarification and/or take that into account when making your decisions.

I am actually working on an updated version of this post which will include some of the newer migration tools available - I hope to have it done in the next month or so.

All the best,

Chris

Hi Chris,

I found the solution :)

below is my solution code:

# Define local Exchange server info for message relay.
$smtpServer = "********";
$FromAddress = "******";
$receiver = "";
$receiver2 = "*******";

# Import user list and information from .CSV file
$Recipients = Import-Csv "F:\list.csv";
$To_Addresses = $Recipients.CREATER_EMAIL_ADDRESS

If ($To_Addresses)
{
$Msg = New-Object Net.Mail.MailMessage
$Smtp = New-Object Net.Mail.SmtpClient($smtpServer)
$Msg.From = $FromAddress
$Cc1 = "********";

# Send notification to each user in the list
Foreach ($Recipient in $Recipients)
{
If($receiver.Length -eq 0)
{
$Msg.to.add($Recipient.CREATER_EMAIL_ADDRESS)
}
Else
{
$Msg.to.add($Recipient.CREATER_EMAIL_ADDRESS)
}

}

$a = Get-Date
"Date: " + $a.ToShortDateString()
$Msg.Subject = "report" ;
$file = "F:\list.csv"
$att = new-object Net.Mail.Attachment($file)
$Msg.Attachments.Add($att)
$Msg.Body = $EmailBody
$Msg.IsBodyHTML = $true
$Smtp.Send($Msg)
}

Else
{
$a = Get-Date
"Date: " + $a.ToShortDateString()
$Msg = New-Object Net.Mail.MailMessage
$Smtp = New-Object Net.Mail.SmtpClient($smtpServer)
$Msg.From = $FromAddress
$Msg.To.Add($receiver2)
$Msg.Subject = "report";
$Msg.Body = $EmailBody_2
$Msg.IsBodyHTML = $true
$Smtp.Send($Msg)
}

$EmailBody = "

&#9888 AUTOMATED REPORT

Hi Team, . Thank you.

Regards,

";

$EmailBody_2 = "

Hi Team, *****

Regards,

";
Write-Host "Email Sent Successful" -ForegroundColor Yellow
**********************************************************************************************************

Thank you Kannan. To add additional addresses, just add them to the "SendNotification" function, e.g

function SendNotification{
$Msg = New-Object Net.Mail.MailMessage
$Smtp = New-Object Net.Mail.SmtpClient($ExchangeServer)
$Msg.From = $FromAddress
$Msg.To.Add($ToAddress)
$Msg.To.Add($ToAddress2)
$Msg.To.Add($ToAddress3)
$Msg.To.Add(ToAddress4@domain.com)
$Msg.CC.Add(ccaddress@domain.com)

Hi Nishant,

You cannot link to a local path for the image. You need to put the image somewhere that is accessible to everyone receiving your email. If you have recipients external to your organization it should be a public url but something to consider is that Outlook is very good at blocking external images in emails.

You could try this:
[html]
<img src="http://path to your web server/One.jpg" alt="Image" height="20" width="200">
[/html]

You could also try to convert the image to base64 and include that. I haven't personally had much success with that method.

Cheers,

CG

Hi Hari,

What you are describing is expected behavior, once a user has been migrated to Office 365 they will no longer be able to access the on-premises ECP. The solution to allow users to continue DG management is to move those DGs to Exchange Online but be aware that users who are on-premises will no longer be able to modify them. There are third-party solutions that help with this as well.

Cheers,

Chris

Wayne,
Chris is wrong. I used his method myself to get around other issues and it creates a mixmatched GUID between the Remote Mailbox object on premise and the mailbox online. Luckily there is a way to fix it manually. Follow the instructions below.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Fix for GUID Mismatch error upon attempted remote mailbox migration:
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
From Exchange Management Console:
===================================
get-remotemailbox –identity "affected user's email id" |fl

From Powershell:
===================
$UserCredential = Get-Credential

$Session = New-PSSession -ConfigurationName Microsoft.Exchange -ConnectionUri https://outlook.office365.c... -Credential $UserCredential -Authentication Basic -AllowRedirection

Import-PSSession $Session

get-mailbox –identity "affected user's email id" |fl

From Exchange Management shell:
===============================

Set-remotemailbox –identity "affected user's email id" –exchangeguid "affected user's actual mailbox GUID"

To answer why selfsigned with cmdlet New-SelfSignedCertificat won't work:

PowerShell command New-SelfSignedCertificate won't work. It hardcodes the wrong crypto provider into the certs it generates. The wrong thing is that it's the provider of the "key store" type, and you won't be able to get the private key out of this certificate. Instead you need to generate the cert with the command makecert.exe that can be downloaded from MSDN as a part of Windows SDK (it will be in a location like C:\Program Files (x86)\Windows Kits\8.1\bin\x64)

Source:
https://blogs.msdn.microsof...
Hey Mark, are you still having this issue?
Thanks for the info Branko

I know this is an ancient post, but I wanted to provide some info as this post still rates high in Google. To generate a self signed certificate that is complient with .Net and can be used by this solution you can use the "New-SelfSignedCertificate" Powershell comannd with the -provider "Microsoft Enhanced RSA and AES Cryptographic Provider" flag. This took way longer to resolve for me than it should have! .Net 4.6 is supposed to resolve this issue.
